ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Just virtual seminars. Not even any office hours
virtual seminar
There was only the live virtual lecture.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned so much about global warming. This class was very sad but super informative and interesting. Learned about the efforts and failures of environmentalism and so so so many ways that oil companies have worked to ruin the world.
I gained a survey-levle understanding of the dynamics at play between knowledge, businesses, politicians, and the environment.
The dysfunctional politics of the US, especially on environmental issues.

This course gave me some valuable insight about the interplay of political dynamics surrounding environmental issues, along with many other related topics. And the introduction to various authors was invaluable as continue my studies. I also honed my writing and presentation skills.
I learned how to write better argument papers. I also learned a lot about environmental politics--especially political sorting and epistemic failure.

I learned about different institutions (including economic, military, cultural) that affect environmental policy as well as the history of the environmental movement. I also learned a lot about the U.S. political system itself.
I learned all about american politics and how they intertwine with environmental policy and (in)action
I gained a great understanding of how the environment relates to politics in America.

I learned a great deal of political theory, and gained a greater understanding of the idiosyncrasies of American democracy. U.S. environmental politics is shaped by a confluence of epistemic, economic, and political factors.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The seminar felt mostly like a lecture. Definitely should include more student conversations. One-on-one meetings with professor halfway through course to check in would be great.

In my opinion, the course was relatively surface-level. The topics covered were ones that do appear current events quite often, so if one isn't especially focused on the news it might appear novel. However, for those with substantial experience with the intersection of business, politics, interest groups, and the environment, this may not be a deep enough exploration of this topic.

Strengths: professor Swenson's analysis of the US political scene over time, truly a pleasure to learn about. He could have done a better job facilitating discussion mid-lecture, but it was tough with zoom
Very little can be improved upon for this course.

The reading list for this course is really, really great. I learned so much about environmental politics--the good and the bad--and argument papers based on weekly readings were fun to write. I also enjoyed presenting about topics of interest to the class.

The class, despite being a small seminar, is mostly just Professor Swenson lecturing about the week's topic. Professor Swenson is a really knowledgeable professor, but lectures seemed slow, and at times, it seemed like Professor Swenson hadn't looked at the slides he was talking about since the previous semester. This felt a little bit like a missed opportunity, considering that I know that many students in the class were just waiting for an opportunity to chime in with thoughts.

Strengths: I liked how each week focused on a clear, distinct topic but also allowed us to see some of the overlap between competing interests. I also appreciated the opportunity for student presentations. The readings were very eye-opening too. Weaknesses: I wish we had more time to specifically discuss the readings, since the seminar was structured more like a lecture.
Amazing professor! The quality he expected for argument papers was very high though which required a lot of work and I am very unsure of my final grade

I learned so much from all the readings, and Professor Swenson clearly knows this topic well. 

I wish there had been clearer guidelines for the student presentations--I didn't really know what I was supposed to do since I did mine at the beginning of the semester. I don't think I understood how open-ended the arguments could be, so I think it would have been helpful to see an list of a sample of arguments that students had made in past years. 

I felt like I would have wanted more guidance about the topic and structure of the final paper. Basically we were given a very brief prompt and told to write a 15 page paper during the last week of class for our final. I didn't expect the final to be such a large undertaking so it would have been good to have more advance notice about what the final would be like.
I think the course could include more discussions rather than only lectures. I think this aspect of the course was hampered by the Zoom format, but it made it difficult to contribute to the course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: More zoom meetings to get the class to know each other.

The class was fairly interactive. I felt that students had enough opportunities to contribute to discussions and ask questions during the lecture.  I imagine the environment was not especially different than the in-class experience of the class.
The pre-planned discussions were hard; it would have worked better to have spontaneous discussions

It is well known that Zoom is not a great medium for class discussion, but little can be done to remedy that issue. The instructor did his best at welcoming students to speak up, and it worked as well as can be expected. The instructors slides could use a little bit of polishing, but the content was clear.
Participating in a seminar is evidently harder via Zoom, but the student presentations made me more engaged and gave us the freedom to dive deeper into a specific topic.
Great virtual learning

Honestly, it was really hard for me to stay engaged in this class with the online format. I felt like Professor Swenson tried to conduct the class as if it was in-person, with no modifications to make it work better over zoom. Unlike in some other seminars I took where professors were focused on creating community and changing things up to fit the zoom format, we never had any discussions in breakout rooms or got to know each other that well. It was really hard to stay attentive for a whole 2 hours on zoom--I think it would have helped if we were given a short break even for just a few minutes in the middle of class or something.
I would recommend using more breakout rooms to facilitate student discussion.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think everyone should take this class. It was so interesting and has made me extremely informed on environmental issues. There are so many misconceptions I hear all the time about the environment and now I have the know-how to rectify them (Thanksgiving arguments with climate denialists). The discussion is very chill and the class isn't demanding. Probably the most relevant to life but least relevant to a job classes I'll ever take.

If you don't have a general understanding of how politics of the environment have played out in the US over the past fifty years, this could be a valuable class to take. If you have extensive experience around this topic, you may want to consider other courses.
Yes

Yes, and my hope as that even non-EVST/PLSC majors would take this course. With anthropogenic climate change beginning to drastically effect many of our societal spheres, it is critical that more people understand what the environmental issues are, and who the promoters/inhibitors of climate action are.

Sure, if you're interested in environmental politics! Professor Swenson isn't teaching the class for much longer, but he's a great man who cares a lot about his students. The reading list and the opportunity to write papers and present is the best part of this class. Discussions, however, are mostly Professor Swenson lecturing about the weekly topic. This can be quite frustrating for students who are looking for a discussion-based class. It is nevertheless a good opportunity to get close to Professor Swenson and meet more people in the sustainability/env. policy field at Yale.

Yes, I thought the material was comprehensive and intriguing. The seminar itself can sometimes feel long, but there is a bit of freedom in the class to explore and write about a specific topic in environmental politics that you're interested in.
Yes! AMAZING course
I would definitely recommend this to anyone interested in environmental policy or environmental law.
I would recommend this course to another student because I learned a great deal about American democracy through the lens of environmental politics.
